{{Infobox Person | name = Jeff Waugh | image = Jeff Waugh by Pascal Terjan.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = Jeff Waugh speaking at [[GUADEC]] | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = [[Australian]] | residence = | other_names = jdub | known_for = Prominence in [[Free Software community]], especially [[GNOME]] and [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]] | education = | employer = Waugh Partners | occupation = Principal Consultant<ref>{{cite web|last=Waugh|first=Jeff|url=http://bethesignal.org/about/|title=About Jeff Waugh|accessdate=2008-07-08}}</ref> | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | signature = | website = [http://bethesignal.org/ Be the signal] | footnotes = }}
'''Jeff Waugh''' (also known as "jdub") is an [[Australian]] [[free software]] and [[open source]] software developer. He is a consultant for Waugh Partners and is known for his past prominence in the [[GNOME]] and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] projects and communities.
== Career ==
In 2004, Waugh was hired by [[Mark Shuttleworth]] as an early employee of [[Canonical Ltd.]] and member of the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu project]], where he worked in [[business development]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ubuntu: A Universal Bond of Sharing|url=http://lwn.net/Articles/102510/|date=2004-09-22|accessdate=2008-05-09|last=Bodnar|first=Ladislav|publisher=LWN.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.osnews.com/story/8286|title=Interview with Jeff Waugh On Ubuntu Linux|last=Loli-Queru|first=Eugenia|date=2004-09-16|accessdate=2008-05-09|publisher=OSNews}}</ref> At [[OSCON]] in 2005, Waugh won "Best Evangelist" in the [[Google-O'Reilly Open Source Awards]] for his evangelism of Ubuntu and GNOME.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=osdir.com|url=http://www.osdir.com/Article6677.phtml|title=Awarded: $25G in Google-O'Reilly Open Source Awards|date=2005-08-02|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Google]]|url=http://code.google.com/opensource/osa-hall-of-fame.html|title=Google-O'Reilly Open Source Awards - Hall of Fame|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref> He announced his resignation from Canonical in July [[2006]] in order to focus more fully on his work in the GNOME project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Waugh|first=Jeff|title=Swimming upstream|url=http://bethesignal.org/blog/2006/07/15/swimming-upstream/|date=2006-07-15|accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref>
From 2007 Waugh and then-wife [[Pia Waugh]] were co-directors of Waugh Partners, an Australian Open Source consultancy launched in 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.computerworld.com.au/index.php/id;765011692|title=Waugh Partners to open up IT industry|date=2006-11-23|accessdate=2008-04-27|last=Gedda|first=Rodney|publisher=Computerworld}}</ref> Waugh Partners won the 2007 NSW State [[Pearcey Award]] for Young Achievers for their work promoting Free Software to the Australian ICT industry.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.computerworld.com.au/index.php/id;1630780103;fp;16;fpid;1|title=Waugh Partners win 2007 NSW Pearcey Award|last=Gedda|first=Rodney|date=2007-12-07|accessdate=2008-05-07|work=Computerworld}}</ref> In 2008 Waugh was a partner of the [[One Laptop Per Child]] Australia program.<ref>{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Ashley|url=http://www.itnews.com.au/News/NewsStory.aspx?story=75455|title=Low cost OLPC program heads down under|date=2008-05-07|accessdate=2008-05-07|work=iTnews}}</ref> {{As of|2010}} Waugh is the sole director of Waugh Partners, since Pia Waugh's move to a new career in 2009.
== Positions ==
Waugh has served in a number of formal and semi-formal positions in Free Software development and community projects: * Director, [[Open Source Industry Australia]], 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://osia.net.au/board|title=Board of Directors|publisher=Open Source Industry Australia|accessdate=2008-06-29}}</ref> * Director, the [[GNOME Foundation]] board, 2003â2004<ref> {{cite mailing list |url=http://mail.gnome.org/archives/foundation-announce/2002-December/msg00005.html |title=GNOME Foundation Elections results official |date=2002-12-21 |accessdate=2008-05-09 |mailinglist=foundation-announce@gnome.org |last=Untz |first=Vincent}}</ref><ref>{{cite mailing list |url=http://mail.gnome.org/archives/foundation-announce/2003-December/msg00005.html |title=GNOME Foundation Elections results are now official |date=2003-12-21 |accessdate=2008-05-09 |mailinglist=foundation-announce@gnome.org |last=Untz |first=Vincent}} </ref> and 2006â2008<ref> {{cite mailing list |url=http://mail.gnome.org/archives/foundation-announce/2006-January/msg00000.html |title=Results for the 2005 Fall Board of Directors Election |date=2006-01-03 |accessdate=2008-05-09 |mailinglist=foundation-announce@gnome.org |last=Mukhopadhyay |first=Sankarshan}} </ref><ref> {{cite mailing list |url=http://mail.gnome.org/archives/foundation-announce/2006-December/msg00007.htmll |title=Results for the 2006 Fall Board of Directors Election |date=2006-12-30 |accessdate=2008-05-09 |mailinglist=foundation-announce@gnome.org |last=Cicek |first=Baris}} </ref><ref> {{cite mailing Sydney Linux Users Group, 2000â2002.<ref name="slug"/> * Member of the linux.conf.au 2001 organising team
== Other Free Software involvement ==
Waugh is an author of the [[Python (programming language)|Python]] [[weblog]] aggregator [[Planet aggregator|Planet]].
